S1.T1.caption: TABLE I: Summary of 3GPP 5G Releases 15-19
S1.T1.table:
Release 15 Release 16 Release 17 Release 18 Release 19
Timeline 07/2017–12/2018 01/2019–06/2020 07/2020–03/2022 04/2022–12/2023 01/2024–06/2025
Evolution type 5G Phase 1 5G Phase 2 5G Evolution 5G-Advanced 5G-Advanced Evolution
Main features SDN - SBA - NFV - network slicing - edge computing - mmWave - mMIMO Private networks - IoT - unlicensed spectrum - positioning - SON NTNs - RAN slicing - mmWave (higher) - NR light - IAB - UAS AI/ML - mobile IAB - dual multi-SIM - mobile small data AI/ML (air interface) - network energy savings - ambient IoT
references: The research on 5G began in the early 2010s in academia and industry. At that time, ITU-R also started its development work toward IMT-2020. The role of ITU-R was to build an overall vision, define performance/service requirements, evaluate candidate radio interface technologies (RITs), and select IMT-2020 compliant (5G) systems by the end of 2020. In 2014, the most cited 5G paper, ”What Will 5G Be?”, was published [12]. In this early phase, this study identified the key elements of 5G, providing important guidelines for further research and development work. The first standardization efforts by 3GPP were taken in 2016. At the end of 2018, 3GPP completed the first standard for the 5G System, i.e., Release 15 [12]. In this early phase, this study identified the key elements of 5G, providing important guidelines for further research and development work. The first standardization efforts by 3GPP were taken in 2016. At the end of 2018, 3GPP completed the first standard for the 5G System, i.e., Release 15 [1]. Release 15 was the first phase of 5G. The second phase, Release 16 [1]. Release 15 was the first phase of 5G. The second phase, Release 16 [13], was finalized in mid-2020. Release 17, a continuation of 5G evolution, was frozen in the first quarter of 2022. Release 18, i.e., 5G-Advanced, was completed by the end of 2023. Currently, Release 19 is in preparation and expected to be finalized by mid-2025. The main features of Releases 15-19 are summarized in Table [13], was finalized in mid-2020. Release 17, a continuation of 5G evolution, was frozen in the first quarter of 2022. Release 18, i.e., 5G-Advanced, was completed by the end of 2023. Currently, Release 19 is in preparation and expected to be finalized by mid-2025. The main features of Releases 15-19 are summarized in Table I.

references: In this section, the main performance requirements are discussed for 6G. In November 2023, ITU-R introduced 15 performance capabilities for IMT-2030 in Recommendation ITU-R M.2160-0, i.e., ”IMT-2030 Framework” [36]. The numerical target values were defined for nine of them. In the following, we review these target requirements and compare them to those of IMT-2020 described in Recommendation ITU-R M.2083-0 [36]. The numerical target values were defined for nine of them. In the following, we review these target requirements and compare them to those of IMT-2020 described in Recommendation ITU-R M.2083-0 [11]. In addition, we present some typical values proposed in the 6G literature (see [11]. In addition, we present some typical values proposed in the 6G literature (see [88], and the references therein). The target requirements are summarized in Table [88], and the references therein). The target requirements are summarized in Table II. At the end of this section, we briefly list the rest of the IMT-2030 capabilities identified by ITU-R. Note that ITU-R has not defined any target values for these capabilities since most of them are difficult to measure numerically.

references: In this section, we discuss three ML methods that can provide diverse benefits to 6G networks. These methods include DL, federated learning (FL), and transfer learning (TL), as illustrated in Figure 10. The opportunities and challenges of these methods are summarized in Table III.

S7.T4.caption: TABLE IV: Summary of spectrum-level technologies for 6G
S7.T4.table:
Spectrum-Level Technologies Vision Description Opportunities Challenges Past Present
THz Communications Extreme capacity for 6G Operation at 0.1-10 THz band Massive spectrum Propagation losses &\&& HW impairm Research since early 2010s 5G mmWave
Optical Wireless Communications Complementary access and backhaul for 6G IR 0.3-400 THz &\&& VLC 400-750 THz &\&& UV 0.75-30 PHz Enormous spectrum &\&& low-cost Blocked easily &\&& reliability issues Research since 2000s (VLC) &\&& 1960s (FSO) Commercial FSO Expermental VLC
references: To fulfill the demanding performance, service, and application requirements of 6G, it is vital to support a massive frequency range from sub-6 GHz and centimeter wave (cmWave) to mmWave and THz bands. At the cost of smaller system bandwidths, lower carrier frequencies with favorable propagation characteristics are preferable for wider coverage and higher mobility scenarios, such as rural areas, wide-area IoT, and high-mobility systems. At the cost of harsher propagation conditions, higher frequencies with larger bandwidths enable higher capacity and throughput in denser network scenarios, such as hotspot, urban, and sub-urban areas. In this picture, THz communication is seen as a promising technology to achieve extremely high data rates. In addition, optical wireless communication (OWC) is a potential candidate to offer complementary frequency resources for special scenarios, such as short-range indoor access and long-range outdoor backhaul links. These two technologies are summarized in Table IV and discussed in detail below.

S8.T5.caption: TABLE V: Summary of antenna system technologies for 6G
S8.T5.table:
Antenna System Technologies Vision Description Opportunities Challenges Past Present
Ultra-Massive MIMO 6G THz umMIMO mMIMO extension High BF gains Cost efficient design mMIMO concept invented in 2010 5G mmWave mMIMO
Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces Controllable wireless environment Electromagnetic metasurface reflectors Energy efficient &\&& low-cost Real-time control &\&& HW design &\&& ch estimation Research since early 2010s RIS prototypes and field-trials
Holographic MIMO Beyond mMIMO technology Electromagnetic metasurface transceivers High spatial multiplexing gains Practical implementations Research since late 2010s Early experiments
references: In the 6G era, antenna systems are expected to be pushed to their limits in the forms of ultra-massive MIMO, RISs, and holographic MIMO (HMIMO). Ultra-massive MIMO is a promising technology to enable THz communication in cellular environments by combating severe propagation losses through high beamforming gains. An RIS is a revolutionary technology to control a wireless environment in a desirable way. HMIMO has the potential to provide very high spatial multiplexing gains due to efficient utilization of spatial dimension. These three technologies are reviewed below and summarized in Table V.

S8.T6.caption: TABLE VI: Summary of transmission scheme technologies for 6G
S8.T6.table:
Transmission Scheme Technologies Vision Description Opportunities Challenges Past Present
Multi-Waveform Scheme Ultra-flexible waveform scheme More than one waveform Supports massive spectrum range Finding suitable waveforms 4G CP-OFDM and DFT-s-OFDM 5G CP-OFDM and DFT-s-OFDM
Advanced Modulation and Coding Methods High-performance modulaton/coding Bits into symbols &\&& error correction High throughput &\&& high reliability High-order mod &\&& coding for URLLC 4G Turbo/conv &\&& up to 256-QAM 5G LDPC/polar &\&& up to 1024-QAM
Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access Next-generation multiple access User separation in power or code More efficient than orthogonal Receiver complexity 5G study item Under study for 6G
Grant-Free Medium Access Massive access Network access wo grant from BS Fast/efficient network access Preamble collisions 4G four-step random access 5G two-step random access
references: The role of a well-designed transmission scheme is crucial for 6G since it determines how efficiently the available spectral resources can be used. In other words, the 6G transmission scheme plays a key role in turning a massive spectrum range into extreme performance to support stringent requirements and a wide range of demanding usage scenarios. To this end, 6G requires an ultra-flexible transmission scheme with novel technological elements. Some potential technologies include highly tunable multi-waveform scheme, advanced modulation and coding methods, efficient NOMA, and fast grant-free medium access, as summarized in Table VI. In the following, we provide a detailed discussion on each of these technologies.

S8.T7.caption: TABLE VII: Summary of network architectural technologies for 6G
S8.T7.table:
Network Architectural Technologies Vision Description Opportunities Challenges Past Present
Integrated Non-Terrestrial and Terrestrial Networks Space-air-ground network access Space-air-ground network layers Global coverage Cost efficiency &\&& industry incentive Satellite commun since 1960s 5G NTNs
Ultra-Dense Networks THz UDNs Highly densified networks Extreme capacity Interference management Denser networks from 1G to 5G 5G mmWave small cells
Cell-Free Massive MIMO Complementary 6G architecture Lots of distributed low-cost APs Stable QoS over network coverage Scalability &\&& clustering Concept invented in 2015 Under study for 6G
Integrated Access and Backhaul THz IAB Same resources for A&\&&B Faster/cheaper to install than fiber Resource alloc between A&\&&B Separated A&\&&B 5G IAB
references: The design of mobile networks is becoming increasingly complex for each new generation. From the network design perspective, 6G is expected to support 3D network architectures, UDNs, flexible cell deployments, and cell-free operations. A 3D network architecture will be enabled by integrating terrestrial and non-terrestrial access, including space, air, and ground layers. Satellite communication is a key technology for global coverage on the land, in the air, and at the sea. Due to THz communications, 6G will rely on an ultra-dense cell design to provide sufficient coverage for extreme-capacity scenarios. Flexible cell deployments will be facilitated by integrating wireless backhaul and access. In addition to the traditional cell-based design, 6G is expected to be complemented by a cell-free network architecture to provide stable QoS in the coverage area. This section provides a detailed discussion on the aforementioned network architectural technologies, i.e., INTNs, UDNs, IAB, and cell-free massive MIMO. These technologies are summarized in Table VII.

S8.T8.caption: TABLE VIII: Summary of network intelligence technologies for 6G
S8.T8.table:
Network Intelligence Technologies Vision Description Opportunities Challenges Past Present
Intelligent Core AI-native core AI-enhanced core Enhanced network management E2E optim &\&& cloud-edge coop Cloud-native 5G AI/ML in 5G-Advanced
Intelligent Edge AI-native edge AI-enhanced edge Enhanced edge management Infra &\&& AI algs &\&& data acquisition Edge computing in 5G AI/ML in 5G-Advanced
Intelligent Air Interface AI-native air interface AI-enhanced air interface Enhanced PHY/MAC Fast changing ch conditions Flexible air interface in 5G AI/ML in 5G-Advanced
references: The ultimate goal of AI/ML is to revolutionize the design, operation, and management of mobile networks by making them more intelligent, efficient, flexible, scalable, automated, proactive, economical, ecological, and secure. While this vision is currently far from reality, the first concrete steps toward it have been taken. AI/ML has been adopted in the 5G standards from Release 18 onward (i.e., 5G-Advanced). In 6G, pervasive AI/ML is expected to be a major leap toward the grand vision. This section discusses how AI/ML can be exploited at different levels of the network, i.e., the core, edge, and air interface. These are the cornerstone of 6G network intelligence, as illustrated in Figure 26 and summarized in Table VIII.

S8.T9.caption: TABLE IX: Summary of beyond-communication technologies for 6G
S8.T9.table:
Beyond-Communication Technologies Vision Description Opportunities Challenges Past Present
Integrated Communication, Computation, and Caching Freeing synergy between 3C Joint design of 3C Expanded capabilities 3C resource management Research since mid-2010s 5G edge computing
Integrated Sensing and Communication Perceptive 6G networks Joint radio sensing and comm Ubiquitous network sensing Trade-off between S&\&&C performance Research since late 2010s Under study for 6G
Wireless Energy Transfer Powering IoT sensors/devices Electrical energy over-the-air Sustainable IoT Efficiency &\&& distance Decades of research Under study for mobile networks
references: The integration of beyond-communication technologies will be a major paradigm shift in the evolution of mobile networks, significantly extending the way how mobile networks can be exploited. The main beyond-communication technologies include computation, sensing, and energy, as shown in Figure 30. Currently, 5G networks have adopted edge computing capabilities and enhanced positioning in its palette of technologies. This paves the way for the broader usage of beyond-communication technologies in the 6G era. Beyond-communication technologies are expected to enable a broad range of novel capabilities and applications for 6G. In the following, we discuss integrated communication, computation, and caching (i3C), ISAC, and WET. These technologies are summarized in Table IX.

S8.T10.caption: TABLE X: Summary of energy-aware technologies for 6G
S8.T10.table:
Energy-Aware Technologies Vision Description Opportunities Challenges Past Present
Green Networks Sustainable 6G networks Energy-efficient design at all levels Ecological and economic benefits High energy consumption Research since early 2010s Energy-efficient design in 5G
Energy Harvesting Sustainable lightweight IoT External energy collection Lightweight IoT devices Efficiency &\&& consumption RF-EH research since 2000s Under study for mobile networks
Backscatter Communications Autonomous low-power IoT External energy to transmit data Battery-free low power IoT devices Low rates &\&& short distances Concept invented in 1940s Under study for mobile networks
references: As the absolute energy consumption is constantly growing, it is of utmost importance to further improve the energy efficiency of mobile networks. In this respect, developing more efficient energy management technologies is one of the main goals and challenges of 6G. In this section, we focus on three energy-aware technologies: green networks, energy harvesting (EH), and backscatter communications. These technologies are summarized in Table X.

references: 6G is expected to support massive amounts of wireless devices, vehicles, and drones, thereby setting diverse requirements for mobile networks. In this picture, D2D, V2X, and cellular-connected UAV communications will play key roles. Each of these end-device-related technologies is discussed below and summarized in Table XI.

Private networks will be at the core of this evolution, offering customized services for vertical clients and creating novel business opportunities. Private networks are reviewed in the following and summarized in Table XII.

S8.T13.caption: TABLE XIII: Summary of security technologies for 6G
S8.T13.table:
Security Technologies Vision Description Opportunities Challenges Past Present
Holistic Network Security Architecture Trustworthy &\&& secure 6G Protection against outside threats Safe use of 6G networks Evolving threat landscape 4G security architecture 5G security architecture
references: Since future society will be highly dependent on 6G, it is of utmost importance to make 6G networks trustworthy and secure. A special attention needs to be paid to privacy as well, as data is becoming more abundant. Therefore, a comprehensive network security architecture is required, as discussed below and summarized in Table XIII.

S11.T14.caption: TABLE XIV: A speculative evolution from 6G to 7G
S11.T14.table:
6G 7G
Disruption
Mobile Intelligence Mobile Hyperverse
Elements
Wireless (Extreme) Wireless (Unlimited)
Artificial Intelligence Deep Intelligence
Internet of Everything Internet of Intelligence
Applications
Human-Machine Interactions Human-DI Interactions
Smart Environments Deeply Intelligent World
Autonomous Systems Intelligent Ecosystems
references: Unlimited wireless refers to virtually unlimited wireless resources in diverse dimensions, including connectivity, computation, control, information, positioning, sensing, and energy. As AI will expand vertically and horizontally in the future, we refer to this advanced level of AI as DI. Due to DI, IoE will evolve toward IoI, which can be seen as a network of deeply intelligent entities. What comes to the 7G-level applications, human-DI interactions refer to diverse types of interactions between people and deeply intelligent entities. Examples include an augmented human, brain-DI interfaces, personal DI, telepathic communications, and holographic worlds. A deeply intelligent world refers to a world enhanced by DI at all levels and scales. Example applications in this domain include global intelligent systems, global monitoring/management/prediction entities, and a deeply intelligent society. Interconnected intelligent ecosystems refer to large-scale entities on the ground, in the air, and at the sea, exploiting wireless, DI, and IoI technologies. The evolution from 6G to 7G is summarized in Table XIV.
